Fair ones! To you who Hearts command
And gently sway, with Fan in hand,
Your favourite Punch a suppliant falls
And humbly for Assistance calls,
He humbly calls, & begs you'·d stop
The Gothick Rage of Vander Hop,
Wh' invades without Pretence or Right
Or any Law but that of might,
Our Pigmy Land──── And treats our Kings
Like paultry, idle, wooden things,
Has beat our dancers out of doors,
And call'd our chastest Virgins, Whores,
He has not left our Queen a Ragg on;
And forc'd our George away and Dragon,
Has broke our Wires, nor was he civil
To Doctor Faustus, or the Devil:
E·'en me, he hurry'd with fell Rage
Most hoarsely squalling off the stage.
And faith our fright was very great
To see a Minister of State,
Armed with Power, & Fury come
To force us from our little Home,
We fear'd, as I am sure we'd reason
An accusation of high treason.
'Till starting up, says Bannameer,
“`Treason my friends we need not fear,
“`For 'gainst the Brass we us'd no power,
“`Nor strove to save the Chancellour,
“`Nor did we shew the least affection
“`To Rochfort on Westmeath Election
“`Nor did we sing Mc̣ ────────
────────────────“Machue he means
“The Villain── I'll dash out thy Brains,
“Tis no affair of State that brings
“Me here, nor Business of the Kings:
“I'm come to seize you all as debtors,
“And bind you fast in Iron fetters,
“From sight of ev'ry Friend in Town
“Till fifty pound to me·'s laid down.
`Fifty quoth I, a devilish Sume
`But stay 'till the New-Half-pence come
`Then we shall all be rich as Iews,
`From Castle down to lowest Stews,
`That sume shall to you then be told,
`Tho' now we cannot furnish Gold.
Quoth he, “Thou lovest Punch to prate,
“And could·'st for ever hold debate,
“But think·'st thou I, have nought to do
“But thus Tuer le temps with you,
“Or dost Thou think that I am come,
“To carry nought but Farthings home,
“Thou Fool, I ne·'er do things by halves,
“Farthings were made for Irish-Slaves
“No Brass for me, it must be Gold
“Or Fifty pound in Silver told,
“That can by any means obtain
“Freedom for Thee, & thy Train.
“Votre tres humble Serviteur
`I'm not in Iest said I, I'm sure
`But from the Bottom of my Belly
`In sober sadness I must tell ye,
`I think it is good reasoning,
`That we, fictitious Men, shoud bring
`Brass Counters made by Wṃ Wood 3}
`Which may as well be understood
`Right Sterling; as we Flesh & Blood,
`And since we are but mimick Men,
`Pray, let us pay in mimick Coin?
`Add too tis said, that you & I,
`Are of the selfsame Family,
`And faith I'm apt to think so too
`For who is liker me than you?
`Iust the same grave and awkward Grace
`Shews forth it self in either Face,
`And each of us, with labour struts
`Behind a Flasket huge with Gutts,
`We tally well in these Respects
`But best of all in Intellects,
`For when you took the diff'erence learned,
`Twixt the words Sorry & Concerned,
`And when upon a grave affair
`Amaz'd, you gaz'd behind a Chair
`Then cry'd── Lord, how like Punchanello
`Is that same fatt-Beef-witted Fellow?
`Then prithy Cousin let us buss,
`Then prithy Cousin let us buss,`And cease to treat your Kindred thus.
Quoth he, “Thou vile mishapen Beast
“Thou Knave am I become thy Iest?

Use all your Interest with the Sec
